pros: Good benefits and decent amount of good colleagues
cons: Pay wise is nowhere as high as European/US banks. Few things to highlights in the technology side: 1) If you're unlucky, you’ll get an old-timer manager who micromanaging a lot and scrutinizes unnecessarily instead of growing the team. 2) Always ask for process improvement including presentation of how other banks (if you’re from another) do things but never accept different perspective. Almost waste of time presenting. 3) They do catch up to other banks like DBS in terms of customer facing applications but lack of centralize systems for internal use. Very behind that of DBS and still using excel like a database. Excel is only as updated as someone willing to update it not a live info. 4) Brought in new technologies to play catch up but always stuck in one or two team because every team is so silo and there’s a lack of direction to cascade to every division. 5) A lot of old timers who doesn’t understand the importance of collaboration between teams. Full of back-stabbing instead. 6) A lot of long working hours in various teams can be reduced significantly if automation is in place. The problem is many people lack exposure on how things are automated in more advance banks, and they think that they must work this long to complete it. 7) Some old managers so call “know-it-all” mindset is actually “know nothing” in European/US banks or even DBS. These people doesn’t even have a Linkedin profile or understand how the modern management works. The list could go on but these are the key problems.

review_title: Avoid local banks at all costs.
pros: Junior staff are more friendly and approachable to ask questions if u are new or need help. They are more team players and willing to do what they can and within office hours (9am to 630pm). Bit of cos, most of them would not do more since they are not highly paid. They would prefer to go back.
cons: Tons! 1. "Seniors" in the team (FVPs and SVPs) are not approachable. They think they know best and always drill on the nitty gritty and waste time trying to align the formats of Word documents and not focused on content. They are not as approachable and talk down to junior people. They will give pages full of comments but will not help to change the wordings (they can do it since they know best, but dont) and expect us to rework n rework and say that we are not up to standard. 2. Long working hours because of these "seniors" and back to back timeliness for tasks to be completed. Even throughout Xmas and CNY. 3. Horrible culture, the seniors will whatsapp and MS teams during weekends and PHs and expect you to respond. if not, they will reply to bosses that the work can't be done cos staff did not reply to them. 4. Do not expect guidance or coaching from seniors. Find your way around to look for helpful teammates or office mates n don't be shy to approach others for help. isn't it sad, that your own team seniors are not helpful!

pros: Who doesn't want to work in a bank, albeit the smallest local bank. Brand sells for itself on the surface. An eye opener for fresh graduates as a stepping stone into the banking and finance sector
cons:
Very toxic environment helmed by a group of dinosaurs (at least in my department). In UOB, you are not recognised by your output, but more like do you know the wee family, and how well connected you are to the management. Everyone works 'hard' and will leave office few minutes after their boss leave for the day. During the exit interview, HR refuse to conduct an exit interview, using an excuse as we know what is happening so there is no need for an interview. 

As HR, it saddened outgoing employees as they are not receptive to feedbacks.

pros: Great staff benefits and bonus payouts. Introduced mental wellness days with workshops to build a more caring workplace.
cons:
1. Extremely long working hours to the point where there is no time to enjoy the staff benefits nor mental wellness initiatives even.

2. Bosses and colleagues have no respect for one's off-work personal time, dragging meetings and contacting you past 7pm

3. Bosses inconsiderate of your workload and capacity, expecting you to do more because of their inability to manage stakeholders or pushback requests from other teams. 

4. Unfair delegation of tasks and projects within the team because of colleagues who are horrible at their jobs. As a result, you will need to shoulder more of the responsibility while your boss just lets the incapable colleagues be.

5. Lack of respect and basic empathy/understanding between departments. Colleagues forcing their way through things, without consideration of teams' bandwith, simply because of business needs. Colleagues may even be condescending and abrasive which adds unnecessary pressure and tension.

review_title: success is dependent on which branch you are in
pros: commission structure is one of the better ones among competitors (but basic is fixed). lots of extra incentives and vouchers to push you to get sales. of cos you will only enjoy all these if you perform well. its basically a money-driven role. promotion criteria is transparent - if you hit targets and meet the requirements, you will be promoted. also, if you do click with your branch mates, you guys will be close-knitted and might still remain in contact even after leaving the company.
cons: very pressurizing role. if you are not hitting targets, be prepared to get bombared by the management almost everyday. long hours - sometimes 11 to 12 hours a day as you have to do cold calls after branch hours. required to work half day on Sat as well. basically, your success is largely dependent on your branch. if you are in a high walk-in branch, then you are blessed and dun even have to cold call. if you are in a low walk-in branch, then good luck to you unless your manager is able to provide good leads for you to cold call. doing cold calls by yourself will be pointless and unproductive, even if your manager told you otherwise. in low walk-in branches, your manager is important and must be able to source for good leads consistently. the role is all about luck and not so much on skills. if you are in a low walk-in branch and still not performing after several months, recommend to leave and look elsewhere, you will not regret.

- very few Singaporeans, mostly foreigners. and you realized work ethics can be very different.

- unreasonable expectations from management
- some team leads are not that kind, especially when you need help from them and they dont assist and blame you for it. 
- internal transfer is just a false glimmer of hope. it never happens and the chances are very very low as you need management's recommendation, and the management will never recommend as the contact centre always falls short on staff

pros: Good work life balance, decent bonus, family friendly place with not as much drinking/happy hours compared to foreign banks (some might see this as a con). Culture is VERY team dependent though; some are very close knit whereas some very toxic. Good place for working mothers; gender equality is apparent though not much racial diversity.
cons: Very Singaporean culture (excessive use of Singlish, follow the rules without much thought), lack of firing means incompetent people get retained, not a flat hierarchy at all (the same rank structure Is used across all departments so it’s extremely transparent how senior or junior someone is; slow to move things along if you’re a junior person; the speed at which people tend to your request if you cc a senior enough person is miraculous; this goes back to the Singaporean culture bit). Legacy systems pose a challenge to digital advancement. Employees’ unwillingness to challenge the status quo and bosses’ lack of support in this area is an impediment to progress.

review_title: All rounded training, positive work environment
pros: Structured, detailed product/compliance/fair dealing training. Genuinely warm superiors and peers. Higher ups care for their people (gave masks to employees when it was short in supply everywhere). Transparent commission structure. Everyone is really serious about doing things right and treating customers fairly. Competitive remuneration and employee benefits. Rather fast to adapt to changing environmental circumstances (e.g. implementation of non face to face sales process during covid).
cons: High sales targets while juggling on job training on systems and processes. Legacy systems can be quite frustrating to use. Too many layers of checks and approvals slowing down paperwork/ administrative processes. Manual, cumbersome retrieval of system information. No empowerment, everything requires approval from higher ups. Very conservative and narrower product suite compared to foreign banks. Modern and progressive front with a hierarchical culture in reality.
